awd_titl_txt: SBIR Phase I:  Artificial Intelligence (AI)-Enabled African Language Database
awd_abstract_narration:
The broader/commercial impact of this Small Business Innovation Research (SBIR) Phase I project is creating a tonally proficient Artificial Intelligence (AI)-enabled translation database for African languages. There are no such product or service that can accurately translate African languages, as African languages have traditionally been under-resourced by Western corporations. By 2050, almost 25% of the earth’s population will be Sub-Saharan African and currently more than 60% of Africans are under 25 years old. The African continent is projected to have $5.6 trillion in consumer and business spending by 2024 and the U.S. is investing over $350 million to expand digital access and literacy and promote U.S. corporate investment in the continent. By expanding opportunities to accurately translate and learn African languages, this project will support economic growth for both the U.S. and African countries and support health and welfare by facilitating communication with African-speaking Americans and recent immigrants. 


African languages are very diverse with more than 2000 distinct languages across the continent. They are difficult for non-native speakers to learn and for translation apps to correctly interpret, primarily due to the tonal and guttural sounds and slight pronunciation differences that make similar sounding words have completely different meanings. The proposed AI-enabled database is first-of-its kind. The project will establish the data processing, model training, and database evaluation steps necessary to produce AI-enabled databases. The goal is to train a database to decipher these tonal shifts and ensure that the correct meaning is conveyed, beginning with a large dataset of correctly spoken audio and visual examples of words and phrases. The primary objective of this project is to develop the entry-level, consistent, Machine Learning (ML) core functionalities and multimodal interactions in a database that can be utilized in the creation of other tonally based language ML/AI databases.

This award reflects NSF's statutory mission and has been deemed worthy of support through evaluation using the Foundation's intellectual merit and broader impacts review criteria.

por.por_cntn:
For our Phase 1 proposed work, ESM Global Productions, LLC embarked on a technically ambitious endeavor to enhance the processing capabilities for African languages, with a particular emphasis on the Yoruba language. We aimed to create a tonally proficient Artificial Intelligence (AI)--enabled translation database for African languages. No such products or services can accurately translate African languages, as African languages have traditionally been considered low-resourced. 

The outcome of our Phase I efforts was the development of an advanced Yoruba language model that extended beyond traditional text-to-text (TTT) functionalities to incorporate speech-to-text (STT) and text-to-speech (TTS) capabilities. This enhancement significantly aligned with our overarching mission, facilitating a digital platform to preserve the oral traditions fundamental to many African cultures. 

We encountered challenges throughout Phase I, especially in data acquisition, processing, and annotation. However, our team's dedication to innovative solutions and problem-solving led to the development of effective strategies to address these challenges. We engaged with linguistic experts, implemented sophisticated data encryption techniques for security purposes, and adopted a hybrid database architecture to manage complex linguistic data efficiently. Furthermore, recognizing the necessity for scalability as we expand our model to encompass additional African languages, we explored state-of-the-art technologies and methodologies to optimize our data collection and annotation processes, ensuring our models' scalability and commercial viability. 

The successful completion of Phase I signifies a critical milestone in our quest to elevate African languages within the digital domain. Our initiatives have not only facilitated increased accessibility to the Yoruba language but have also contributed to the preservation of its cultural heritage. As we advance to Phase II, we anticipate further refining our database, incorporating additional languages, and more. 

The outcomes of Phase I underscore the transformative potential of artificial intelligence and machine learning technologies in fostering cultural inclusivity and preservation in the digital landscape. At ESM Global, we are at the vanguard of this transformative journey, bridging linguistic divides and championing the diverse tapestry of African languages and cultures. Our commitment remains steadfast, and we are poised to leverage the insights and methodologies garnered in Phase I to introduce ground-breaking African language solutions on a global platform.
